results.title: I Think they think: overcoming social phobia
results.creator_credit: Christopher Thomas, Christine Mason and Monkey See Productions
results.brief_description: Three sufferers of social phobia, a devastating anxiety disorder, share their experiences with the condition and the techniques they used to successfully overcome it. The techniques are based on cognitive behaviour therapy, which has proven to be successful in most treatment of social phobia. The program is intended for sufferers, family and friends, and health care workers. It covers defining social phobia, monitoring anxiety, cognitive behaviour therapy, managing anxiety through meditation, and medication.

results.title: I think they call him John
results.creator_credit: John Krish, Jack Carruthers and Samaritan
results.brief_description: John Cartner Ronson spends a typical Sunday alone with his memories in his home in a huge block of London flats. Old miner, old soldier, old gardener, and old age pensioner, he has been living on his own since his wife died nine years ago. An old man’s life has become the ultimate expression of that much discussed twentieth century condition, the failure of communication.

results.title: I think it's going to rain today
results.creator_credit: Center for Digital Storytelling US, ACMI and Joan Hobson
results.brief_description: The icy winter storm of abuse that a 14 year-old boy can bring upon a family. The unleashing of anger to deliberate acts of violence. Summer will come again but it will just take awhile.

results.title: I think
results.creator_credit: Gene Feldman and Wombat Productions, Inc.
results.brief_description: Deals with the difficulties facing children as they struggle to develop individual identities. Linda, a 10 year old, is subject to a variety of pressures to think and act as other people wish. Considers group identity, influence of the media, family and teachers.

results.title: I taught them but they didn't learn (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Sue Mogg, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the attitudes which children from low socio-economic backgrounds bring to school. Teachers’ attitudes can affect children’s learning, so the attitudes of teachers are also examined. The intention of the film is to make teachers aware of the ‘culture gaps’ which can occur between groups of children.

results.title: I Still know what you did last summer
results.creator_credit: Danny Cannon, Neal H. Moritz and Global Entertainment Productions
results.brief_description: Producer of “I know what you did last summer” Neal H. Moritz commented that “I Know” was positioned perfectly with the success of “Scream”, “Party of five” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” Its sequel, “I still know what you did last summer,” without such support in its marketing campaign, was left to prove itself in a sea of teen horror films, all trailing in the wake of “Scream.” “I Still know” reunites us with our heroine, Julie James (Jennifer Love Hewitt), at university, far away from Southport where the horrors of last summer (and the summer before that), took place. The nightmares of the meat-hook-wielding fisherman are preventing Julie from putting the brutal murder of her best friend, Helen (Sarah Michelle Gellar), behind her. Luckily, Julie has made a new best friend, Karla (Brandy), who has won a trip to the Bahamas and convinces Julie to go with her and some other friends. They arrive only to discover that it’s the off-peak season and, with the exception of ‘marginally trained off-season staff’, they are alone on the island. Julie’s nightmares become a reality upon discovering the fisherman is on the island seeking his revenge. Julie is forced to fess up to her friends about her tormented past as they struggle for their lives knowing they are caught in total isolation. Refreshingly, “I Still know” has subscribed to the new paradigm of teen horror, whereby the protagonist teen character is given personality and a surname. With a supporting cast that is less disposable than the teenager characters of slasher films of the past, “I Still know” is more suspenseful and more frightening, and a horror film that can stand on its own merit. Cast includes: Jennifer Love Hewitt, Brandy, Freddy Prinze Jr., Mekhi Phifer, Muse Watson.

results.title: I Stand alone = Seul contre tous (D)
results.creator_credit: Gaspar Noe, Lucile Hadzihalilovic, Les Cinemas de la Zone and Alliance Atlantis
results.brief_description: An unemployed butcher returns to his native Paris after having bashed his lover and forced her to miscarriage. With 300 francs in his pocket and a gun with three bullets in his hand, he is filled with venomous bile for a world he believes has consistently oppressed him and denied him his dignity. “I Stand Alone” is an assured debut feature by Gaspar Noe, extending his previous short film that was based on the same main character. Set in 1980, the film explores a post-industrial world in which capitalism has seemingly no more need for the labourers and workers which it previously employed to generate wealth. As the butcher walks the graffiti strewn desolate streets of northern Paris, passing shut down factories and warehouses, he is continually giving vent to destructive homophobic, misogynist and racist fantasies, blaming everyone except himself for the alienation and menial servitude of his life. Employing startling effects of sound and editing to simulate the increasing paranoia and madness of its protagonist, “I Stand Alone” is an alarming and terrifying exploration of a society that has seemingly lost all egalitarian and communal values; a society in which the accumulation of wealth and the integrity of exchange are the only values and ethics that count. By the end of the film, as the butcher degenerates into complete solipsism and lunacy, he articulates a value system for this new age based on idolisation of rape, incest and murder. The film is as a passionate, ambiguous and disturbing exploration of the attraction of neo-fascism for the French indigenous working class. In French with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Critic’s Prize at the 1998 Cannes Film Festival)

results.title: I spell I can't...I can!
results.creator_credit: Edie Collet, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Edie Collet’s beginnings were difficult - her mother died giving birth and she was diagnosed as being handicapped. Collet was raised by her father and siblings to become an educated, well travelled and independent adult. Collet was told she would never work but she proved them wrong. This story is dedicated to Collet’s dad.

results.title: I Shot Andy Warhol [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mary Harron, Tom Kalin, Christine Vachon, BBC-TV, Samuel Goldwyn Company and Playhouse International Pictures
results.brief_description: A fact-based drama about Valerie Solanas, the lesbian feminist writer who achieved her fifteen minutes of fame after shooting Manhattan pop artist/guru Andy Warhol in 1968. Solanas was a peripheral figure in Warhol’s Factory studio scene in New York during the late Sixties, and the founder and sole member of her ‘Society for Cutting Up Men’ (SCUM). Her SCUM manifesto has since become a feminist classic. The film focuses on her troubled life, as broke, homeless and psychologically unstable she turns to begging and prostitution to survive. Convinced that Warhol’s support could change her life, she becomes violently enraged when the artist and his friends begin to turn away from her. Cast includes Lili Taylor, Stephen Dorff and Jared Harris.
